Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: so to out-perform visa we need another 47k/second...what‚Äôs the relationship between chain count and tx?

Content: [telegram] <CryptoVitamins> https://twitter.com/julianhosp/status/1010867268140482561?s=21 guys co-founder of Tenx asked if there's ever been a ltc eth swap. We finally got his attention and he gave us a shout out. Go on there and comment!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: more chains, more capacity

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you need double the capacity, double the number of chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you need 100x, then 100x the chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: KMD is now leading in dPoW security, JUMBLR privacy, scaling and atomic swaps

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: nice, so this will theoretically tell us the exact number of chains to hit 60K/second

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: is a chain defined as a full node?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a chain is defined as a blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you know, like bitcoin

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: bitcoin seems to work pretty well, so we just replicate chains over and over

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: right, but what do you mean when you say 64...

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: ah gotcha

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: that‚Äôs what I was asking

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 64 different chains means 64 chains that are all different

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems about 6400 chains will hit 1 mil tx/sec

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: Jeez

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nobody ever said it was easy to do

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: haha

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it can be done by replicating working tech, ie. the basic bitcoin protocol blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no magic needed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and unlike other scaling proposals, we secure each of these chains with dPoW

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: That would be 64000 instances running, correct? so 64K VMs could handle this?

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: right. so they are bitcoin-level secure out of the box

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: i want to write an article on this, thus my questions, gotta wrap my little mind around and see how it can easily be communicated to people who glaze over when they hear the word ‚Äúchain‚Äù

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the problem with having many chains is that there are many chains, so how does one chain interact with te other, let alone all 6400 of them

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is where our MoMoM tech comes in

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: ah right

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: I was reading up on that yesterday

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: audo has good materials on that, but the essence is that we add to the notarization data, additional levels of merkle data tha tallows any chain to validate any other chain's tx, as long as KMD is around to create the proofs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this ability allows to create a burn protocol, so that coins can be burned on one chain and recreated on another

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: Could mpich be used to run multiple instances of a daemon and essentially individual chains?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what is mpich

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: quick and dirty super computer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no user has to run all the chains, they would just run the ones they care about

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: allows you to tie together cpu threads from many servers on a network to run a process multiple times

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so however the usage is localized, users would use the few chains they need

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we use komodo assetchains, so you launch a new komodod for each chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assuming a geographic allocation of chains, you would have citywide chains, countywide, statewide, nationwide

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so most people just have their city's chain locally

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if they are travelling to a different city, they convert to the new city's chain

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: right was just thinking that through, so where is the bottleneck then...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a bit of prep work but at least it is possible and it can all be automated

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the burn protocol takes 2 to 3 notarizations, which automatically builds in security to the process, but it does take half hour or so

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: so in a sense the user experience is massive tx capacity and the notarization can continue on without impacting the performance users experience?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notarization only impacts a user when they are transferring coins from one chain to another

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then they need to wait 2 or 3 notarizations

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: okay, i see

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all the rest of the time, the notizations just happen, securing the chain

Author: Oliver Westbrook#7752
Content: very nice.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no need to break things into unsecured shards, when the blockchains are already independent

Content: and dPow secured
